Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story:
Every Sunday evening, I call my parents, just like I always do. It’s our tradition, and I know how much it means to them. Tonight, as I dial, I’m sitting at the kitchen table, staring at the plate of cookies my mom sent last week. She baked them herself, just like she used to when I was little. But this time, she tried a new recipe, and I can see from the label that one of the ingredients isn’t kosher. I know she meant well—she just wanted to surprise me with something special. 

As the phone rings, I feel a knot in my stomach. I want to tell her how much I appreciate the cookies, how much I love her for thinking of me. But I also know she’ll ask if I tried them, and I can’t lie. I want to make her happy, to be the good child who shares everything and makes her proud. At the same time, I want to honor my commitment to keeping kosher, something that’s become so important to me. The phone clicks as she answers, and I’m caught between wanting to make her smile and staying true to my beliefs.
